Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s first entry into that particular camp called ‘Night Of The Living Dead’ spawned nine additional movies, as well as several popular theatrical sequels by other filmmakers. With popularity apparent, studios wanted in on this zombie action flick cash cow.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Polish director Agnieszka Holland’s style.
Holland initially appears to be positioning this movie as an attack against British colonialism; indeed Finn’s family arrives shortly after the ship which has brought them from England and is bombed by Maori tribe members who believe their passengers are invincible warriors.

After watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice the parallels between it and another film called America 3000. Both were very bad mid 1980's scifi movies that feature a girl who fantasizes about robots (like Wall-e) making her life better. In both cases she risks everything to escape into a Utopia like one ruled by robots.
The only difference was that in America 3000, her boyfriend comes along as his role is diminished.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the wave of martial arts popularity ; It borrows many characteristics and themes from Asian and American cinema alike, while substituting thick, delicious Texan accents with those of epileptic convulsions.
